title: Developmental and Comparative Immunology
abstract: Corals are comprised of a coral host and associated microbes whose interactions are mediated by the coral innate immune system. The diversity of immune factors identified in the Pocillopora damicornis genome suggests that immunity is linked to maintaining microbial symbioses while also being able to detect pathogens. However, it is unclear which immune factors respond to specific microbe-associated molecular patterns and how these immune reactions simultaneously affect coral-associated bacteria. To investigate this, fragments of P. damicornis and P. acuta colonies from Taiwan were subjected to lipopolysaccharide (LPS) treatment to stimulate immune responses and measure bacteria community shifts. RNA-seq revealed genotype-specific immune responses to LPS involving the upregulation of immune receptors, transcription factors, and pore-forming toxins. Bacteria 16S sequencing revealed significantly different bacteria communities between coral genotypes but no differences in bacteria communities were caused by LPS. Our findings confirm that Pocillopora corals activate conserved immune factors in response to LPS and identify transcription factors coordinating Pocillopora corals' immune responses. Additionally, the strong effect of coral genotype on gene expression and bacteria communities highlights the importance of coral genotype in the investigation of coral host-microbe interactions.

abstract.text: Corals are comprised of a coral host and associated microbes whose interactions are mediated by the coral innate immune system. The diversity of immune factors identified in the Pocillopora damicornis genome suggests that immunity is linked to maintaining microbial symbioses while also being able to detect pathogens. However, it is unclear which immune factors respond to specific microbe-associated molecular patterns and how these immune reactions simultaneously affect coral-associated bacteria. To investigate this, fragments of P. damicornis and P. acuta colonies from Taiwan were subjected to lipopolysaccharide (LPS) treatment to stimulate immune responses and measure bacteria community shifts. RNA-seq revealed genotype-specific immune responses to LPS involving the upregulation of immune receptors, transcription factors, and pore-forming toxins. Bacteria 16S sequencing revealed significantly different bacteria communities between coral genotypes but no differences in bacteria communities were caused by LPS. Our findings confirm that Pocillopora corals activate conserved immune factors in response to LPS and identify transcription factors coordinating Pocillopora corals' immune responses. Additionally, the strong effect of coral genotype on gene expression and bacteria communities highlights the importance of coral genotype in the investigation of coral host-microbe interactions.

body_text.text: Interactions between animal hosts and their associated microbiomes are fundamental processes that influence host traits, ecology, and evolution (Wilkins et al., 2019) . The innate immune system maintains homeostasis between the animal host and associated microbes by relying on pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) to detect microbe-associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) and activate downstream signaling cascades and effector responses (Eberl, 2010; Nyholm and Graf, 2012) . Stony corals (Family Scleractinia) are ideal for the study of invertebrate host-microbe interactions, because of the diversity of associated symbiotic microbes, and because of the complex coral innate immune system (Palmer and Traylor-Knowles, 2012; Thompson et al., 2015) . Corals associate with numerous microorganisms including endosymbiotic algae (Symbiodiniaceae), bacteria, viruses, and micro-eukaryotes (Thompson et al., 2015) . One of the biggest outstanding questions in coral biology is how the coral innate immune system interacts with these symbiotic microorganisms when confronted with pathogens.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Scleractinian corals possess a complex innate immune system with numerous PRRs, signaling pathways and defense mechanisms activated in response to various MAMPs (Palmer and Traylor-Knowles, 2012) . Pocillopora damicornis, a weedy Indo-Pacific coral, is a valuable model for investigation into coral innate immunity. The P. damicornis genome possesses a diversification of innate immunity genes (Cunning et al., 2018) , and several P. damicornis transcriptomic studies have found an upregulation of innate immune genes such as Toll-like receptors (TLRs) in response to the coral pathogen Vibrio coralliilyticus (Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2014 Zhou et al., 2019) . This extensive diversification of innate immune genes is thought to be linked to the maintenance of specific coral-microbe symbioses (Bhattacharya et al., 2016; Cunning et al., 2018; Poole and Weis, 2014; Shinzato et al., 2011) , however it is still not well understood how the immune system responds to other MAMPs beyond Vibrio coralliilyticus, or how these immune reactions may affect corals' native microbial community.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To examine how MAMP exposure can affect coral gene expression https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dci.2020.103717 Received 9 January 2020; Received in revised form 17 April 2020; Accepted 17 April 2020 T and native bacterial communities, the immune stimulant lipopolysaccharide (LPS) can be used. LPS is a potent endotoxin found in the cell walls of gram-negative bacteria (Alexander and Rietschel, 2001; Gilmore, 2006) . Previously, LPS has been used to induce an innate immune response involving the activation of TLRs, lectins, and the NF-κB pathway in Indo-Pacific and Caribbean coral species (Fuess et al., 2017 (Fuess et al., , 2016 Kvennefors et al., 2010; Williams et al., 2017) . However, these studies did not account for coral genotype-specific responses and did not examine the effects on coral-associated bacteria communities. To build on these previous studies, we examined the effects of LPS exposure on coral gene expression and bacteria community composition of four genotypes of Pocillopora from southern Taiwan. We found that LPS activates a common set of transcription factors, and that LPS exposure does not change the overall composition of the coral-associated bacteria. Additionally, we found evidence for genotype-specific immune responses and coral-associated bacterial communities, despite the common set of transcription factors. Overall, our results emphasize the importance of genotypic variation in coral immune responses and highlight the differences in bacteria communities associated with different coral genotypes.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Pocillopora spp. coral colonies were collected from two reefs within Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan, Houwan (2 colonies: HW1, HW2) and Wanglitung (2 colonies: WT1, WT2) ( Supplementary Fig. 1 ). Colonies were brought to flow-through seawater systems under ambient sunlight at the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium (NMMBA) and acclimated for a two-week period before fragmentation. Colonies were then split into 2 cm 2 fragments and allowed to recover for another three weeks.
body_text.section: Coral study site, collection, fragmentation and acclimation

body_text.text: Triplicate fragments of each genotype were placed into individual autoclaved 400 mL glass jars filled with 1 μm-filtered seawater and randomly assigned to either the LPS exposure or seawater control treatments (24 fragments total). Blue and white LED lights were operated on a 12h:12h day/night cycle and temperature was maintained at 28°C for the 72-h duration of the experiment and was recorded at 1min intervals with HOBO® data loggers (Onset, MA, USA). Corals were exposed to 10 μg/mL LPS (E. coli O127:B8 LPS purified by phenol extraction, Sigma-Aldrich) over 4 h ( Supplementary Fig. 2 ), as in other studies that have used LPS to stimulate coral immunity (Fuess et al., 2017 (Fuess et al., , 2016 . To attain a final concentration of 10 μg/mL, 1.6 mL of 2.5 mg/mL LPS stock solution was administered with a micropipette directly into the filtered seawater in each 400 mL jar. After LPS exposure fragments were sampled using stainless steel cutters that were cleaned in 70% ethanol between samples. Fragments were then preserved in RNA stabilization solution at room temperature for 30 min and then frozen at −80°C. Frozen samples were transported to the University of Miami Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science in coolers on dry ice for further processing.
body_text.section: Experimental LPS exposure

body_text.text: Total mRNA was isolated from the coral fragments using the Qiagen RNeasy Kit. RNA concentration and purity were quantified using a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer (ThermoFisher). cDNA was created using the Illumina TruSeq RNA Library Prep Kit v2 (Illumina) according to the manufacturer's protocol and quantified using the Qubit dsDNA BR kit (ThermoFisher Q32853). cDNA was then shipped overnight on dry ice to the University of Utah's Huntsman Cancer Center for 50-bp single-end sequencing on the Illumina HiSeq 2000 platform. A second sequencing batch was completed for 7 low-depth samples to obtain a minimum depth of 8 million reads, after which 23 samples (control treatment n = 11, LPS treatment n = 12) were analyzed.
body_text.section: RNA extraction, cDNA library preparation and sequencing

body_text.text: 2.4. RNAseq quality control, sequence alignment, and statistical analyses FASTQ files were checked for base pair quality using FASTQC, trimming of adapters and poor quality bases were done using Trimmomatic v0.36 (Bolger et al., 2014) . Trimmed reads were aligned against the P. damicornis genome using STAR v2.5.3a in two-pass mode (Cunning et al., 2018; Dobin et al., 2013) . Unsorted binary alignment map (BAM) files containing the aligned transcripts were quantified using the featureCounts command in the Subread program (Liao et al., 2014) . Statistical analysis of differential gene expression was carried out in R version 3.5.2 using DESeq2 according to the de-sign~Batch + Genotype + Treatment (Love et al., 2014) . Average log2-fold change (LFC) for each gene was estimated by comparing normalized gene expression counts between treatments. Significantly differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified based on a false discovery rate-adjusted p-value (FDR p adj ) cutoff of < 0.01. Coral genotype-specific effects were examined with additional DESeq2 models:~Batch + Treatment.
body_text.section: RNA extraction, cDNA library preparation and sequencing

body_text.text: Pocillopora mitochondrial open reading frame (mtORF) sequences were extracted from coordinate-sorted BAM files for each genotype. A 904-bp consensus mtORF sequence was extracted for each genotype, and multiple sequence alignment was performed to identify the closest mtORF haplotype in GenBank ( Supplementary Fig. 3 ) (Flot and Tillier, 2007; Gélin et al., 2017) .
body_text.section: Pocillopora spp. mtORF haplotype identification

body_text.text: Gene ontology (GO) enrichment was completed using topGO (Alexa et al., 2006) . GO terms corresponding to the "Biological Process" (BP) were annotated to genes in the P. damicornis genome and tested for enrichment using the "weight01" algorithm in topGO, with significant enrichment determined using Fisher's exact tests and a significance threshold of p < 0.05.
body_text.section: Gene ontology functional enrichment analysis

body_text.text: Total DNA was extracted using the Qiagen DNeasy PowerSoil kit from all fragments (Weber et al., 2017) . PCR amplification of the V4 region of bacterial 16S gene using primers 515F and 806RB with singleindexed Illumina adapters according to the Earth Microbiome Project protocols (Apprill et al., 2015) . PCR amplicons were checked on a 1.5% TE-agarose gel, and PCR amplicon concentration was determined using a Qubit dsDNA BR kit (ThermoFisher Q32853). All amplicons were purified using AMPure XP beads and 80% ethanol washes, then normalized to 4 nM and pooled for submission to the University of Miami Center for Genome Technology for 300 bp paired-end sequencing on the Illumina MiSeq.
body_text.section: Bacteria DNA extraction and 16S rDNA amplicon sequencing

body_text.text: Raw 16S sequence reads were processed using the QIIME2 pipeline version 2020.2 and the plugin DADA2 (Callahan et al., 2016) was used to remove primer sequences, trim poor-quality bases, dereplicate reads, identify chimeric sequences and merge paired-end reads. Bacterial 16S rRNA sequences were taxonomically classified using the plugin q2feature-classifier (Bokulich et al., 2018 ) and a Naïve Bayes Classifier previously trained on the SILVA 16S rRNA database (Quast et al., 2013) QIIME2 release based on the 515F/806RB primer pair at the 99% level (available at https://docs.qiime2.org/2020.2/data-resources/). The plugin q2-taxa was used to remove all mitochondria and chloroplast sequences from the dataset, and the BIOM tables containing bacteria taxa counts, phylogenetic trees and sample metadata were exported from QIIME2 and imported into R for statistical analyses.
body_text.section: Bacteria community 16S rRNA sequence assembly, quality control and taxonomic assignment

body_text.text: All bacteria community statistical analyses were conducted using R version 3.6.3 packages phyloseq, ggplot2, vegan, and ALDeX2 (Fernandes et al., 2014; Mcmurdie and Holmes, 2013; Oksanen et al., 2019) . Bacteria community analyses were conducted at the amplicon sequence variant (ASV) level (Callahan et al., 2017) , and raw sequences were not rarefied (McMurdie and Holmes, 2014). Alpha diversity was calculated using the Chao1 richness, Simpson evenness and Shannon diversity indices. Nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis tests were used to test for significant differences between treatments, reef sites, and coral genotypes (Xia and Sun, 2017) . Beta diversity was calculated using Bray-Curtis dissimilarity matrices and visualized using Principal Coordinates Analysis (PCoA). Tests for homogeneity of multivariate dispersions (PERMDISP) (Anderson et al., 2006) confirmed homogeneity of variances, and permutational analysis of molecular variance (PER-MANOVA) (Anderson, 2017) was used to test for significant differences in beta diversity between treatments, reef sites and coral genotypes. Welch's t-tests implemented in ALDeX2 were used to test for differentially abundant bacterial ASVs between treatments.
body_text.section: Bacteria community 16S rRNA statistical analyses

body_text.text: Raw mRNA and 16S amplicon sequence reads were deposited into the NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under accession PRJNA587509. All of the scripts written in bash and R programming languages used in the RNAseq and 16S data analysis are available on GitHub.
body_text.section: Sequence availability and analysis code

body_text.text: (https://github.com/michaeltconnelly/EAPSI_Pocillopora_LPS).
body_text.section: Sequence availability and analysis code

body_text.text: cDNA library sequencing of the 24 Pocillopora spp. tissue samples yielded 328.3 million raw reads, additional sequencing read depth and mtORF haplotype results can be found in supplemental data (Supplementary Table 1 , Supplementary Fig. 3 ). In the overall comparison between LPS treatment and control treatment samples, there were 167 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) with a false-discoveryrate adjusted p-value less than 0.01. Of these 167 DEGs, 95 were upregulated (LFC > 0, p adj < 0.01) and 72 were down-regulated (LFC < 0, p adj < 0.01) (Fig. 1A) . Several upregulated DEGs were identified as immune genes, and could be classified as being involved in recognition, signaling, or effector responses (Supplementary Table 2 ).
body_text.section: Differential gene expression analysis reveals LPS-responsive immune genes

body_text.text: Five immune recognition genes were differentially expressed in response to LPS, including two TLRs, two Deleted-in Malignant Brain Tumors-1 (DMBT-1) and fibrinogen C-domain containing protein (FIBCD1) (Thomsen et al., 2011) . Signaling intermediates and transcription factors were also significantly differentially expressed, including hepatic leukemia factor (HLF) and hairy/enhancer-of-split with YPRW motif (HEY), ETS-related transcription factors ELF-4 and ELK-1, phosphoinositide 3-kinase adapter protein 1 (PIK3AP1), and poly [ADPribose] polymerase (PARP-14). Additionally, several enzymatic effectors including laccase-4 enzyme (LCC4), heme-binding protein 2 (HEBP-2), membrane attack complex pore-forming (MACPF) domaincontaining proteins perforin-2 (MPEG-1) and DELTA-alicitoxin Pse2b (PsTX-60B) were differentially expressed in response to LPS.
body_text.section: Differential gene expression analysis reveals LPS-responsive immune genes

body_text.text: A principal component analysis (PCA) of overall gene expression showed that the effect of Pocillopora spp. genotype was stronger than the effect of LPS exposure (Fig. 1B ). HW1 and HW2 cluster separately from WT1 and WT2, with PC1 separating HW1 (P. damicornis type 8a) from the WT1 and WT2 and explaining 41% of the total variance and PC2 separating the HW2 (P. damicornis type 4a) samples and explaining 23% of the total variance. Both HW1 and HW2 appear to be more different than WT1 and WT2 (P. acuta type 5).
body_text.section: Pocillopora spp. genotype differences are the primary source of variance in coral gene expression

body_text.text: Genotype-specific DESeq2 models generated separate clusters from control and LPS, indicating a clear effect of LPS treatment on gene expression ( Supplementary Fig. 4 ). HW1 had 53 DEGs, and HW2 had 61 DEGs and only 8 DEGs were shared. WT1 had 69 DEGs and WT2 had 74 DEGs and only 14 DEGs were shared ( Fig. 2A) . In total 213 DEGs were detected in at least one genotype-specific DESeq2 model, and 322 DEGs were detected across the general LPS response model and the genotypespecific models ( Supplementary Fig. 5, Supplementary Table 3 ). Only 6 genes were consensus DEGs across four genotypes (Fig. 2B) .
body_text.section: Pocillopora spp. genotype differences are the primary source of variance in coral gene expression

body_text.text: Further analysis of the Venn diagram intersections of DEGs in each of the genotype specific DESeq2 models ( Fig. 2A ) revealed remarkably unique DEG sets for each genotype in response to LPS. HW1 had 41 unique DEGs, and the HW2 had 41 unique DEGs. WT1 had 51 unique DEGs, and WT2 had 53 unique DEGs. Many of the unique genotypicspecific DEGs were identified as immune related including several Gprotein coupled receptors (GPCRs) only differentially expressed in HW2 or WT2, and ETS-like transcription factors only differentially expressed in HW1 (ELF-2) or WT2 (ELK-1) ( Supplementary Fig. 5 , Supplementary  Table 3 ). Fig. 1 . DESeq2 results reveal genotype-specific gene expression patterns and upregulation of coral innate immunity genes during LPS exposure. A. Volcano plot depicting differential gene expression between the control and LPS treatment. Log 2 fold-change (LFC) is on the x-axis, and the significance value (-log 10 p adj ) is on the y-axis. Significant DEGs (p adj < 0.01) are colored red or blue, and all other non-DEGs are dark grey. B. PCA of control and LPS treatment samples reveals that the effect of genotype explains the majority of the variance in gene expression. Point shape represents the genotype, and color represents the treatment, with blue = control treatment and pink = LPS treatment. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)
body_text.section: Pocillopora spp. genotype differences are the primary source of variance in coral gene expression

body_text.text: In the list of upregulated DEGs, the significantly enriched Biological Process GO terms included regulation of transcription (Table 1) , and GO terms associated with downregulated DEGs included ammonium transport, serine family amino acid metabolic process, alpha-amino acid biosynthetic process, cation transmembrane transport, oxidationreduction process, purine ribonucleoside biosynthetic process, pteridine-containing compound biosynthetic process, and dicarboxylic acid metabolic process (Table 1) .
body_text.section: Gene ontology enrichment analysis reveals activation of transcriptional regulation processes

body_text.text: A total of 1,668,806 demultiplexed reads from all 24 samples were obtained, with an average sequence length of 300 bp. 1391 amplicon sequence variants (ASVs) were detected after filtering. The topmost abundant bacterial phyla identified were Proteobacteria, Bacteroidetes and Cyanobacteria (Fig. 3) . Within Proteobacteria, the relative abundance was dominated by Gammaproteobacteria (75%), Alphaproteobacteria (23%) and Deltaproteobacteria (2%) ( Supplementary Fig. 7 ). Within Gammaproteobacteria, relative abundance was dominated by Oceanospirillales (62%), Alteromonadales (22%), and Cellvibrionales (2%) ( Supplementary Fig. 7 ). Within Oceanospirillales, ASVs belonging to the genus Endozoicomonas were present in all colonies with overall prevalence of 83% in 20 of 24 samples ( Supplementary Fig. 7) .
body_text.section: Bacteria community results demonstrate no significant differences due to LPS exposure

body_text.text: Despite the hypothesis that shifts in the coral-associated bacteria community might be detected after LPS exposure due to the observed induction of coral innate immunity, there were no significant differences in bacteria communities between treatments detected by PERM-ANOVA (Treatment: F = 0.88, df = 23, p = 0.551). However, reefspecific and genotype-specific differences were identified (Reef: F = 2.67, df = 23, p = 0.005; genotype: F = 4.05, df = 23, p < 0.001). PCoA of sample Bray-Curtis dissimilarities confirm these differences ( Supplementary Fig. 7 ). Additionally, nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis tests revealed no significant effects of treatments on Chao1 richness, Simpson evenness and Shannon diversity indices. Furthermore, no ASVs were differentially abundant between treatments according to ALDeX2 tests ( Supplementary Fig. 8 ).
body_text.section: Bacteria community results demonstrate no significant differences due to LPS exposure

body_text.text: Previous studies using LPS have collectively found differential expression of PRRs, signaling pathways, and effector mechanisms in response LPS, indicating that corals activate evolutionarily conserved immune responses (Fuess et al., 2017 (Fuess et al., , 2016 Kvennefors et al., 2010) . In this study, we observed a similar pattern, where LPS caused upregulation of immune including TLRs, ETS-related transcription factors, and perforin-2 ( Fig. 1, Supplementary Table 2 ). Additionally, despite the upregulation of immune gene expression, no changes in coral-associated bacteria community were observed, indicating that LPS is suitable for studying corals' immune responses without interfering with the native coral-associated bacteria community.
body_text.section: LPS treatment activates an evolutionarily conserved immune response

body_text.text: Additionally, we found that the upregulation of TLRs and DMBT-1 in response to LPS corroborates previous reports of coral immune factors responding to bacterial MAMPs (Supplementary Table 2 ) (Fuess et al., 2017 (Fuess et al., , 2016 Williams et al., 2017) . Human DMBT-1 contains scavenger-receptor cysteine-rich domains and can exist as a membranebound PRR or as a secreted glycoprotein capable of agglutinating bacteria and activating the complement system (Leito et al., 2011) . Due to this broad utility and activation in response to LPS, DMBT-1 may have a role in maintaining coral mucosal immunity and microbial homeostasis.
body_text.section: LPS treatment activates an evolutionarily conserved immune response

body_text.text: We also identified multiple upregulated transcription factors including ELF-4, ELK-1, HEY and HLF. ELF-4 plays regulates perforin Fig. 2 . Consensus effects of LPS on gene expression. A. Venn diagram of the 6 consensus DEGs shared among all the genotype specific DESeq2 models and upregulated in response to LPS exposure. B. Heatmap of the 6 consensus DEGs that depicts the rlog transformed expression values for each gene, with color scaled from red for overexpression to blue for underexpression relative to the mean expression level. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.) Table 1 Significantly enriched GO terms for sets of differentially expressed genes. expression and lymphocyte generation (Lacorazza et al., 2002; Suico et al., 2017) while ELK-1 regulates inflammatory gene expression (Supplementary Table 2 ) (Guha et al., 2001 ). HEY and HLF were both upregulated in the overall DESeq2 model and in the genotype-specific model, indicating their potential as central, conserved transcriptional immune regulators (Fig. 2B ) (Hu et al., 2017; Komorowska et al., 2017) . These observations suggest Pocillopora corals possess a broad transcriptional repertoire that regulates immune functions such as inflammation. Future studies identifying transcription factor binding sites will help in our understanding of the regulation of immune factors in corals (Dimos et al., 2019) . Multiple effector genes were also upregulated including PIK3AP1, PARP-14, MPEG-1 and PsTX-60B (Supplementary Table 2 ). PIK3AP1 links TLR signaling to PI3K activation, a process that prevents excess cytokine production (Maruoka et al., 2005) . PARP-14 is similarly involved in the modulation of the extrinsic coagulation cascade, macrophage activation and protection of lymphocytes against apoptosis (Cho et al., 2009; Iwata et al., 2016) . These two genes may function in corals to prevent excessive inflammation and ensure cell survival following immune challenge. MPEG-1 and PsTX-60B are pore forming proteins with MACPF domains that can initiate bacterial lysis (Benard et al., 2015) . This is the first evidence in corals of LPS-induced upregulation of pore-forming proteins, which likely have critical roles in bacterial lysis.
body_text.section: LPS treatment activates an evolutionarily conserved immune response

body_text.text: Taxonomic classification within Pocillopora remain the subject of debate (Poquita-Du et al., 2017) , but intra-generic and genotype-specific differences in gene expression have been previously documented (Poquita-Du et al., 2019) . In this experiment genotype was the main driver of gene expression, with different coral genotypes exhibiting different immune gene expression patterns in response to LPS. For example, the ETS-like transcription factors were uniquely differentially expressed among genotypes and this may affect downstream function like the onset of inflammation, apoptosis, and/or autophagy (Fuess et al., 2016) . These genotypic differences may also reflect adaptation of different coral genotypes to different environmental conditions and microbial associations. Future studies of Pocillopora coral gene expression should aim to include the maximum number of genotypes possible and ensure correct species identification by using, at minimum, the mtORF marker to differentiate genotypes (Johnston et al., 2017) .
body_text.section: Pocillopora corals demonstrate genotype-specific immune responses to LPS treatment

body_text.text: Only consensus six genes were differentially expressed in all of the genotype specific DESeq models and upregulated overall in response to LPS treatment. Three were transcription factors (HEY, HLF, and BHLHE40) involved in immune regulation and cell differentiation, one was a circadian rhythm protein cryptochrome, and the other two had no annotation (Hu et al., 2017; Jarjour et al., 2019; Komorowska et al., 2017) . In corals, HEY has been shown to be upregulated in response to Vibrio coralliilyticus and Oceanospirillales bacteria challenge in Montipora aequituberculata, leading to the hypothesis that HEY is an important modulator for coral immune cell differentiation (van de Water et al., 2018) . HLF maintains mammalian quiescent hematopoietic stem cells during LPS treatment and (Komorowska et al., 2017) BHLHE40 is involved the mediation of macrophage proliferation and repression of inflammatory cytokines (Jarjour et al., 2019) . Collectively the upregulation of these transcription factors indicates a tight immune transcriptional network that is responding to LPS. Coral cryptochromes are responsive to light, and have a circadian rhythm involved in the timing of spawning. In other model systems, cryptochromes have been implicated in immunity through their indirect modulation of cytokine expression (Cao et al., 2017; Narasimamurthy et al., 2012) . While this interaction is not understood within Pocillopora, it may reflect a connection between circadian rhythm and immune response (van de Water et al., 2018) . Future investigation into these genes, in particular the transcription factors, will tell us more about the mechanisms underlying immune response, and subsequent downstream targets.
body_text.section: The six consensus Pocillopora LPS-responsive DEGs include transcription factors and immune signaling intermediates

body_text.text: Our results on bacteria community composition were similar to previous studies of Taiwan Pocillopora corals (Brener-Raffalli et al., 2018) , however with coral genotype being the primary driver of differences. Considering the strong genotype effects on both gene expression and bacteria community composition, it is likely that coral host immunity-microbiome interactions may exert control over the structuring of their bacteria communities (Epstein et al., 2019; van de Water et al., 2018; Ziegler et al., 2019) . Coral immune systems can distinguish between pathogenic versus commensal bacteria (van de Water et al., 2018) and possess a large diversity of PRRs that enable specificity in MAMP recognition (Cunning et al., 2018; Poole and Weis, 2014). Furthermore, P. damicornis and their bacterial communities were Fig. 3 . LPS exposure has negligible effects on the coral bacteria community. A stacked barplot of relative abundances of bacteria phyla, including Proteobacteria, Bacteroidetes, and Cyanobacteria. These are the dominant communities in all samples.
body_text.section: Pocillopora coral genotype affects the bacteria community composition

body_text.text: shown to be locally adapted different environments, with immune genes identified as outlier loci contributing to the observed genetic differentiation between habitats (van Oppen et al., 2018) . In future experiments, the selection of alternate LPS variants from different bacteria strains may produce different immune reactions and reveal alternate immune receptors and pathways. 4.5. Pocillopora spp. bacteria community is not directly altered by shortterm LPS exposure There were no significant differences in coral-associated bacteria community alpha and beta-diversity between fragments in the control versus LPS exposure treatments, and also no differentially abundant ASVs between treatments. This suggests that acute exposure to LPS does not induce shifts in the overall coral-associated bacteria community composition or the relative abundance of bacterial taxa. In the microbiota of the mouse lung, differences in the bacteria community composition were observed following the intratracheal injection of LPS, however, these differences were only observed after three days post injection (Poroyko et al., 2015) . In this experiment the lack of significant differences in the coral-associated bacteria community between control and LPS treatment samples could be due to the short duration LPS exposure. In the future, sampling at later time points may yield detectable shifts in the coral-associated bacteria community.
body_text.section: Pocillopora coral genotype affects the bacteria community composition

body_text.text: This study demonstrates the conserved immune pathway response to LPS while highlighting the role of coral genotype in driving both gene expression and bacteria community abundances. We hypothesize that different coral genotypes have specific immune responses that are regulating their bacterial microbiomes and involved in resilience against pathogens. Altogether, our results are consistent with previous studies of other corals and provide the basis for future investigation into the influences of coral genotype and bacteria community composition on the dose-response, timing, and cell-specificity of corals' innate immune responses to bacterial MAMPs and infectious pathogens.
body_text.section: Conclusion

back_matter.text: The authors would like to thank the scientists and research support staff at the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium, especially Ray Tan for field assistance and site environmental data collection. Additional thanks to Dr. Anderson Mayfield for sharing laboratory space at the NMMBA, and to Dr. Stephanie Rosales and Dr. Ross Cunning for bioinformatics assistance. Funding was provided by the National Science Foundation (NSF) East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) Program, award #1713962 to Michael T. Connelly.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.dci.2020.103717.
